connections.description: Major
connections.details: There is at least one major connection between the books which will enhance your understanding of the plot and the Cosmere. Reading in this order is highly recommended, and reading out of order may be spoilery.

connections.description: Significant
connections.details: There is at least one significant connection between the books which may enhance your understanding of the plot and the Cosmere. Reading in this order is recommended.

connections.description: Minor
connections.details: There is at least one minor connection between the books which may enhance your understanding of the plot and Cosmere in a small way.

connections.description: Easter Eggs
connections.details: There is at least one subtle reference between the books which may hint at something bigger going on. Easter eggs may be very difficult to spot unaided.

categories.details: Stories not part of a series.
Forthcoming works with a planned release target or which are being actively worked on. Expected publication dates may be in parenthesis. Titles may be tentative.
Future cosmere story plans with a relatively high likelihood of being written, based on the frequency of mentions or other empahasis. Titles are tentative.
Potential cosmere story ideasa that are less certain, based on the frequency of mentions or other lack of empahasis. Titles are tentative.
Uncanonical works which are publicly available, both excerpts and complete.
The idea of the greater Cosmere plays a small role, with connections generally being little more than easter eggs.
This phase involves more direct Cosmere references and serves as a transition from Phase 1 to Phase 3.
Cosmere connections are common and notable, but series are still mostly isolated and distinct.
Cosmere connections are heavy, but series are still mostly isolated and distinct.
Includes all planned future cosmere stories. Likelihood of publication varies. Known publication dates may be in parenthesis. Titles are tentative.
Includes unpublished, apocryphal stories. Some elements may be part of the official continuity. Some may be published in the future while others will not.

appearances.description: Hoid
Khriss
appearances.details: Khriss's appearances (solid) and mentions (outline), not counting the Ars Arcanum.

appearances.description: Nazh
Ars Arcanum
appearances.details: Stories that include an Ars Arcanum.

children.title: Elantris
children.chronology: Occurs long before Mistborn Era 1, but not thousands of years before. However, this is subject to change.

appearances.description: Hoid's first appearance. Hoid is the beggar that works with Sarene in Chapter 58. The tenth anniversary edition includes a postscript with Hoid in it.
Nazh's annotations can be found on the map of Sycla.

connections.description: The map in Elantris refers to 'Rose Barbarians'. There are mentions of Svorden, Teod, and Sycla. When escaping the palace, Shai runs into a Derethi priest (wearing red armor). When she steals the painting she inscribes an Aon Reo in its place.
The Ire are Elantrians. Their symbol is Aon Ire.

Galladon appears in Interlude I-1 as 'Grump'. Note his use of 'sule' (friend) and 'kolo' (understand) as well as the Dula word 'kayana' (crazy). Also, Aona and Skai are mentioned in the Chapter 22 epigraph.
Riino, the lighthouse owner in Chapter 97, is the Hoed Raoden and Galladon lowered into the mountain lake.
The nature of Sel's magic is discussed in the Selish system essay.
The communication box used by Shallan to communicate with Mraize and Hoid contains a Seon.
Codenames is Kaise; she communicate with Kelsier using Seon Dao in Chapter 40. Shay-I (Moonlight) uses AonDor in Chapter 54.

The Sorceress is an Elantrian, and Aonic text is found in her tower's corridor. Hoid finally succeeds in becoming an Elantrian after failing to do so in the Elantris postscript. Hoid and the Sorceress both use AonDor.
Design says that Yumi is Invested to the same level as an Elantrian. Hoid compares the hijo to seons.

children.title: The Hope of Elantris
children.chronology: Shortly after the events of Elantris, and concerning events during the end of that book.

children.title: Elantris 2
children.chronology: A short time jump is planned between Elantris books, with the original main characters still being alive. But this is subject to change.

children.title: Elantris 3
children.chronology: A short time jump is planned between Elantris books, with the original main characters still being alive. But this is subject to change.

children.title: The Emperor's Soul
children.chronology: After Elantris, but within the characters' lifetimes. Note this could place it prior to Elantris 2 and/or 3.

appearances.description: The 'Imperial Fool' is Hoid.

connections.description: A deleted prologue that contains some canonical elements.
The nature of Sel's magic is discussed in the Selish system essay.
The Fused refer to aluminum as Ralkalest.
Moonlight is Shai; she uses Forgery on several occasions and takes on the name 'Shay-I' after using her Essence Mark to become an Elantrian.

children.title: Mistborn: The Final Empire
children.chronology: <a target='_blank' href='https://wob.coppermind.net/events/176/#e8494'>Mistborn Era 1 occurs prior to The Stormlight Archive.

appearances.description: Kelsier meets with Hoid in Chapter 19.
Annotations by Nazh can be found on the map of Luthadel.

connections.description: 'Kenton Street' in Chapter 17 (also mentioned in The Well of Ascension) is a reference to Kenton. Trell the foreman is connected to Trelagism.
Steel and iron tools are used to 'push' and 'pull' on aether. The 'Push for every Pull' quote in Tress of the Emerald Sea Chapter 63 is attributed to Kelsier.

Hoid suggests that tin Allomancy would allow someone to see through the shroud. Hoid and Design steal a spaceship to reach the Iron Seven Waystation, presumably a Scadrian space station based on the name.

children.title: The Eleventh Metal
children.chronology: Concerns Kelsier's training, years before Mistborn: The Final Empire.

children.title: The Well of Ascension
children.chronology: <a target='_blank' href='https://wob.coppermind.net/events/176/#e8494'>Mistborn Era 1 occurs prior to The Stormlight Archive.

appearances.description: Hoid is among the Terris refugees in Chapter 56, according to Brandon.
Annotations by Nazh can be found on the map of Luthadel.

connections.description: Lemex's nurse is a Terriswoman.
Ati speaks to Vin and others with Ruin's Pure Tone. The Well of Ascension pulses with Preservation's Pure Tone
Ulaam credits 'the Father' for the invention of the scalpel.

children.title: The Hero of Ages
children.chronology: <a target='_blank' href='https://wob.coppermind.net/events/176/#e8494'>Mistborn Era 1 occurs prior to The Stormlight Archive.

appearances.description: Hoid is the informant that Vin was supposed to meet with in Chapter 27.
Annotations by Nazh can be found on the map of Luthadel.

connections.description: Demoux appears in Interlude I-1 as 'Thinker'; Ishikk mishears his name as 'Temoo'. Ruin's vessel, Ati, is mentioned in the Chapter 18 epigraph. Felt worked for the House Venture on Scadrial.
Wit appears to use emotional Allomancy in Chapter 45.
The Part 2 epigraphs include a letter from Sazed to Hoid. Felt reveals he is from another world.
The Scadrian system essay discusses the events that occurred in The Hero of Ages.

The Part 2 Epigraphs are a letter from Harmony. Fabrial metals have similar effects as in the Metalic Arts. Gereh and Axindweth are Feruchemists. Raysium is associated with Odium as atium is associated with Ruin.

The Beaconites are searching for a Scadrian spaceship. The Scadrian spaceship has an Awakened steelmind on board. Nomad compares the prospector ships to the abilities of Seekers. The Night Brigade knows how too use a Hemalurgic spike made from one person to track a Dawnshard to a different holder.

children.title: The Alloy of Law
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 2 occurs after Stormlight Archive book 5 and before Stormlight Archive book 6.

appearances.description: Hoid is the beggar speaking with Lord Joshin and Lady Mi'chelle in Chapter 4.
Annotations by Nazh can be found on the map of Elendel.

connections.description: Trell the foreman is connected to the god Trell.

children.title: Allomancer Jak
children.title2: Allomancer Jak and the Pits of Eltania, Episodes 28-30
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 2 occurs after Stormlight Archive book 5 and before Stormlight Archive book 6.

children.title: Shadows of Self
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 2 occurs after Stormlight Archive book 5 and before Stormlight Archive book 6.

appearances.description: Hoid is Wax's coachman, named in Chapter 7.

children.title: The Bands of Mourning
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 2 occurs after Stormlight Archive book 5 and before Stormlight Archive book 6.

appearances.description: Hoid is the beggar who gives Wax a special coin in Chapter 11.
Khriss is the woman who dances with Wax in Chapter 12. Khriss and Nazh are also the 'K or N' referred to in the 'Do your metal tools speak to you?' ad in The New Ascendancy broadsheet.

Nazh is 'the haunted man' in 'The Ghastly Gondola!' story in The New Ascendancy broadsheet. (note his 'shadows' curse) Khriss and Nazh are also the 'K or N' referred to in the 'Do your metal tools speak to you?' ad in the broadsheet.

connections.description: Kelsier's survival is revealed in The Bands of Mourning.

children.title: Mistborn: Secret History
children.chronology: Happens concurrently with Mistborn Era 1.

appearances.description: Hoid is 'Drifter'.
Kelsier meets Khriss and Nazh in the Cognitive Realm.
Kelsier meets Khriss and Nazh in the Cognitive Realm.

connections.description: Hoid and Frost discuss the events of The Hero of Ages (and Mistborn: Secret History).

Thaidakar, leader of the Ghostbloods is Kelsier, with the fight between him and Hoid in Secret History specifically referenced. Scadrial is referenced in Ialai's notes. The device used by the honorspren to store Stormlight came from the Ire.
Riina, the Sorceress, is a member of the Ire. Hoid refers to Kelsier as an old adversary in Tress of the Emerald Sea Chapter 63.

children.title: The Lost Metal
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 2 occurs after Stormlight Archive book 5 and before Stormlight Archive book 6.

appearances.description: Hoid is Wax's coachman, named for the first time in Chapter 7.
Nazh is 'the haunted man' in 'Nicki Savage and The Compass of Spirits' story in The Two Seasons broadsheet.

connections.description: Jan Ven, mentioned in the 6th Epilogue, is a Sho Dela species of beings known from Dragonsteel Prime.

Ulaam was first mentioned in The Lost Metal. 'Death himself, with nails in his eyes' refers to Marsh, whose personification as 'Death' is spreading across the cosmere according to the The Lost Metal Ars Arcanum. Rosite is used by TwinSoul. Sazed is said to have 'released' the kandra, seemingly sometime after The Lost Metal.
The aliens living on UTol are Sho Del--beings which made their first canonical appearance in MeLaan's epilogue in the Lost Metal.

The TimeTellers are a Scadrian political faction who seem to primarily speak Malwish. Nomad considers stealing a jar of purified Dor from them. The Cinder King uses Scadrian technology similar to an ironmind to weigh Nomad down.

children.title: Book of Nails
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 2 occurs after Stormlight Archive book 5 and before Stormlight Archive book 6.

children.title: Ghostbloods 1
children.chronology: Fifty to seventy years after Mistborn Era 2. After Stormlight Archive book 10. Prior to Mistborn Era 5.

children.title: Ghostbloods 2
children.chronology: Fifty to seventy years after Mistborn Era 2. After Stormlight Archive book 10. Prior to Mistborn Era 5.

children.title: Ghostbloods 3
children.chronology: Fifty to seventy years after Mistborn Era 2. After Stormlight Archive book 10. Prior to Mistborn Era 5.

children.title: Cyberpunk Mistborn 1
children.chronology: A cyberpunk Mistborn series would be in a near-future setting, between Eras 3 and 5.

children.title: Cyberpunk Mistborn 2
children.chronology: A cyberpunk Mistborn series would be in a near-future setting, between Eras 3 and 5.

children.title: Cyberpunk Mistborn 3
children.chronology: A cyberpunk Mistborn series would be in a near-future setting, between Eras 3 and 5.

children.title: Space Age Mistborn 1
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 5 is the finale of the cosmere storyline.

children.title: Space Age Mistborn 2
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 5 is the finale of the cosmere storyline.

children.title: Space Age Mistborn 3
children.chronology: Mistborn Era 5 is the finale of the cosmere storyline.

children.title: Warbreaker
children.chronology: Occurs after Mistborn Era 1 and before The Stormlight Archive.
children.link: Full text: Brandon's website | Alternate file types

appearances.description: Hoid is the master storyteller in Chapter 32.

connections.description: Zahel is Vasher. Szeth's new Shardblade is Nightblood. Mraize's collection in Chapter 43 includes a Tear of Edgli flower.

Azure is Vivenna; she uses Awakening on several occaisions and has an Awakened sword. Nightblood and Vasher make significant appearances. Nightblood mentions Denth, Shashara, and Vivenna by name. A painting from the Court of Gods appears in Chapter 102. Riino mentions Heightenings. Hoid uses Awakening in the Epilogue.
The Dawnshard causes Rysn to experience several effects similar to the Heightenings associated with Breath.

Nightblood is used to kill Rayse. Ialai's notes mention Nalthis. Zahel uses Awakening in his fight against Kaladin and explains that he is a Cognitive Shadow. The coin Adolin gives to Kaladin and some merchants in Lasting Integrity are from Nalthis. Endowment is referenced in the Chapter 24 epigraph. Odium tampers with Hoid's Breath in the Epilogue.
Nalthis is mentioned in Chapter 39. Moonlight describes an Awakened lock in Chapter 40.

Fort's tablet is Nalthian technology that utilizees with Awakened predictive Connection circuits. The metal soldiers are Awakened. Ulaam mentions the use of 'Awakener's arts' to make animals talk. Xisis the dragon uses Awakening.

Design compares Yumi's level of Investiture to that of a Returned. Hoid says the machine was Awakened. (though it's unclear if Breath was involved) The black smoke from the shroud is reminiscent of the black smoke that bleeds from Nightblood.

'Breath Equivalent Units' are a measurement system for Investiture based on BioChromatic Breath. Breath is mentioned, and Nomad attempts to use an altered version of 'my Breath become yours' to transfer Investiture. A steelmind is described as Awakened (though it's unclear if Breath is involved).

children.title: Nightblood
children.chronology: This sequel occurs prior to The Stormlight Archive.

children.title: The Way of Kings
children.chronology: Occurs after Mistborn Era 1 and Warbreaker but before Mistborn Era 2.

appearances.description: Hoid is 'Wit'.

connections.description: In Part 5 Chapter 2 Kelsier sees an alerter fabrial (the glowing yellow gemstone in a golden metal lattice).
Baon appeared in The Way of Kings Interlude I-1 as 'Blunt'.

The Ghostbloods were first seen in The Way of Kings. Moonlight mentions Odium in Chapter 20. Codenames mentions Roshar and the Thaylen script in Chapter 39. The 'people with golden hair living on the east side', mentioned by Maraga in Chapter 32, are probably Iriali.
Midnight Essence was first seen in The Way of Kings, where it is associated with Nahel bond is referenced in Tress of the Emerald Sea chapter 31.

Hoid narrates the story to Rosharans: Painter is described as looking Veden but with paler skin than you would find on Roshar, rice grains are compared to those on Roshar, he mentions being on Komashi for three Rosharan years, he mentions chulls and chasmfiends, he compares the heat of the ground to the beaches of the Reshi Isles, compares the spirit lights to using spheres for light, mentions Cultivation, mentions a plant native to Roshar called a duluko, and uses the Shin honorific suffix '-nimi'. A fabrial is used to measure Nikaro's levels of Investiture, with results that seem to display in women's script. The spirits and nightmares are similar to spren in the way they respond to humans.

Roshar and various nationalities, including the Azish, Alethi, Veden, and Thaylen, including their cultures and customs, are featured prominently. Nomad looked for Taln's_Scar, a Rosharan constellation, in Chapter 28.

children.title: Words of Radiance
children.chronology: Occurs after Mistborn Era 1 and Warbreaker but before Mistborn Era 2.

appearances.description: Hoid is 'Wit'.
Nazh is the ardent trying to get a sketch of Bridge Four's tattoo in Chapter 31. Several drawings and sketches also include his annotations.

connections.description: Iyatil is of Southern Scadrian descent, made apparent by the mask she wears, and was the first appearance of their people in the books.
With powers gained from the lerasium he took, Hoid used emotional Allomancy in Chapter 45.
Mraize's collection in Chapter 43 includes a vial of sand from Taldain.
The man Hoid speaks with is Frost, who responded to Hoid with similar opinions in the Words of Radiance Part 4 epigraphs.
The Rosharan system essay covers details about Roshar and makes mentions of Odium's past.
Wayne buys some chouta from a street vendor in Chapter 32. Dlavil is Iyatil's brother.

Lumar is a stop on the Iriali 'Long Trail' sometime after they leave Roshar. Hoid states that the weather patterns on Lumar 'aren't specifically Invested' and 'aren't self-aware' in the way that highstorms are. Hoid makes a metaphor about loaning one's best flute only to people who can be trusted with it, seeming to make a gibe at Kaladin for losing his.

children.title: Elsecaller
children.chronology: Occurs concurrently with Words of Radiance.
children.link: An early partial draft, written by Sanderson, was posted online in August 2014.

children.title: King Lopen
children.title2: King Lopen the First of Alethkar
children.chronology: Occurs concurrently with the final events of Words of Radiance.

children.title: Edgedancer
children.chronology: Occurs after Words of Radiance and concurrently with the early events of Oathbringer.

appearances.description: Hoid is 'Ol' Whitehair', mentioned in Chapter 12.

connections.description: Masaka is a Sleepless.

children.title: Oathbringer
children.chronology: Occurs after Mistborn Era 1 and Warbreaker but before Mistborn Era 2.

appearances.description: Hoid is 'Wit'.
Several drawings and sketches include Nazh's annotations. Most notably, the glyphs page is entirely written by him.

connections.description: The Way of Kings Prime, written in 2002, is the original draft of The Way of Kings. Only small excerpts were released prior to Oathbringer as Brandon felt it contained spoilers for certain ideas through that book. It was self-published as a Sanderson Curiosity in July 2020.
The nightmares, and to some degree the shroud, appear similar to Midnight Essence.

children.title: Dawnshard
children.chronology: Between Oathbringer and Rhythm of War.

connections.description: The Sleepless first explained the nature of Dawnshards to Rysn, including the danger they present to the cosmere and the care with which they must be protected. She was specifically warned against bonding a spren and becoming a Knight Radiant, perhaps in part to prevent something like what happened to Aux.

children.title: Rhythm of War
children.chronology: Occurs after Mistborn Era 1 and Warbreaker but before Mistborn Era 2.

appearances.description: Hoid is 'Wit'.
Several drawings and sketches include Nazh's annotations. Most notably, the glyphs page is entirely written by him.

connections.description: Microkinesis referes to a type of magic from Yolen in Dragonsteel Prime.
Xisis is almost certainly the 'Foil' mentioned in the Ars Arcanum who is described as 'deep within his ocean' and wishing 'to achieve control over the aethers.'

Design plays a significant role in the story, having been given the appearance and semblance of a body with a complex Lightweaving. Hoid says 'we all kind of learned our lesson' on giving actual bodies to spren, which likely refers to Ishar's experiments on spren. Hoid's 'protections' that turned him into a statue seem to have been created in response to what happened when Odium tampered with his memories in the Rhythm of War epilogue. The spirits can be bound into devices like spren into fabrials.

Nomad/Zellion is Sigzil, a member of Bridge Four and a Knight Radiant. He mentions several events from his training with Kaladin while they are bridgemen, and later while he is Kaladin's squire. The Knights Radiant and their spren are detailed over the opening books of The Stormlight Archive, including the way they develop their powers through the swearing of oaths and the nature of their Shardblades and Shardplate. Nomad considers the use of tones and vibrations to manipulate Investiture, as one can do with Stormlight.

children.title: Wind and Truth
children.chronology: Occurs after Mistborn Era 1 and Warbreaker but before Mistborn Era 2. Some events in the finale overlap with Mistborn Era 2.

children.title: Horneater (2026)
children.chronology: Fills in what happened with Rock during and after the events of Rhythm of War.

children.title: Stormlight Archive 6
children.chronology: There's a roughly 15 year gap between Stormlight 5 and 6. Occurs after Mistborn Era 2 and before Mistborn Era 3.

children.title: Stormlight Archive 7
children.chronology: There's a roughly 15 year gap between Stormlight 5 and 6. Occurs after Mistborn Era 2 and before Mistborn Era 3.

children.title: Stormlight Archive 8
children.chronology: There's a roughly 15 year gap between Stormlight 5 and 6. Occurs after Mistborn Era 2 and before Mistborn Era 3.

children.title: Stormlight Archive 9
children.chronology: There's a roughly 15 year gap between Stormlight 5 and 6. Occurs after Mistborn Era 2 and before Mistborn Era 3.

children.title: Stormlight Archive 10
children.chronology: There's a roughly 15 year gap between Stormlight 5 and 6. Occurs after Mistborn Era 2 and before Mistborn Era 3.

children.title: Chasmfriends
children.chronology: Occurs concurrently with the final events of Words of Radiance.

children.title: The Dog and the Dragon
children.title2: The Dog and the Dragon picture book

children.title: The Girl Who Looked Up
children.title2: The Girl Who Looked Up picture book

children.title: White Sand (graphic novels)
children.chronology: White Sand occurs prior to Elantris.

appearances.description: Hoid is the hooded man with a stringed instrument who first appears in Ais's first scene in the middle of Chapter 4. He plays a song in the Epilogue.
Khriss is a main character.

connections.description: Wit has a jar of black sand from Taldain in Chapter 67, which turns white after Shallan Lightweaves.
Taldain is referenced in Ialai's notes. Navani uses sand from Taldain to measure Investiture in her experiments.
The Taldain system essay discusses Taldain and sand mastery.
Canticle's sun is Invested similar to Taldain's.

children.title: White Sand (prose rewrite)
children.publication: Originally planned for December 2025. Delayed. Current plans unknown.
children.chronology: White Sand occurs prior to Elantris.

children.title: The Arcanist
children.chronology: Described as a sequel, so presumably occurs shortly after White Sand.

children.title: Shadows for Silence
children.title2: Shadows for Silence in the Forests of Hell
children.chronology: Occurs before Stormlight Archive but after Warbreaker.

connections.description: Mraize's collection in Chapter 43 includes a silver knife from Threnody.
The silvery chain in Celebrant is from Threnody.
Kelsier causes the Ire to suspect Shades from Threnody are nearby.
The Threnodite system essay discusses the history of Threnody.
Raboniel's chain from 'the lands of the dead' is likely a silver chain from Threnody.
Silver is used to cut aether and kill aether spores. Lumar's seas are said to be relatively shallow compared to the Lilting Abyss on Threnody.
Design says that Komashi is stranger than any world she's been to, including Threnody.

The Threnodites were first seen in Shadows for Silence in the Forests of Hell. Shades are seen and mentioned, including the Chorus and those used by the Night Brigade. Nomad mentions Forests of Hell, the Evil.

children.title: Sixth of the Dusk
children.chronology: Shortly before Mistborn Era 5.

connections.description: Mraize's chicken, mentioned in Chapter 22, is an Aviar. Patji is referenced obliquely in Autonomy's letter to Hoid in the Part 2 epigraphs.
The Drominad system essay discusses First of the Sun and its magic.
Gereh has an Aviar, which Lift comes into possession of.

Hoid refers to a story about Linji, likely a figure from First of the Sun, who attempted to travel around the world without the use of Aviar. This reference strongly suggests that the audience listening to the story is from First of the Sun.

children.title: Isles of the Emberdark (2025)
children.chronology: Five years after Sixth of the Dusk novella.

children.title: Kingmaker
children.chronology: The reading suggests a setting not long after Sixth of the Dusk.

children.title: Dragonsteel 1
children.chronology: Dragonsteel is the first series in the cosmere storyline.

children.title: Dragonsteel 2
children.chronology: Dragonsteel is the first series in the cosmere storyline.

children.title: Dragonsteel 3
children.chronology: Dragonsteel is the first series in the cosmere storyline.

children.title: Arcanum Unbounded (essays)
children.chronology: The essays were written before the events of Sixth of the Dusk. They could potentially be as early as Mistborn Era 3.

appearances.description: Khriss is the author of the essays.

connections.description: Devotion and Dominion are referenced in the Chapter 26 Epigraph. Ambition's struggle with Odium is referenced in the Chapter 27 Epigraph.

Moonlight references the death of Devotion and Dominion in Chapter 40. Autonomy currently resides in the Taldain system. Dlavil speaks with a Silverlight accent. MeLaan receives a note from Harmony with Silverlight Mercantile stamped on the envelope.

Nomad sees a planetary guidebook and mentions films from Silverlight. When seeking to enter the TimeKeepers' spaceship, he cites the 'Refugee and Lost Expatriate Bill' under the 'Silverlight Codes of Interplanetary Conduct'. Zellion is said to be a Yolish name.

children.title: Tress of the Emerald Sea
children.chronology: The story takes place three hundred years after the Iriali have departed Lumar. It also occurs after Stormlight Archive 1-5 (based on several references) in which the Iriali are present on Roshar still. It is unclear where the story falls relative to the Arcanum Unbounded essays, Sixth of the Dusk, and Mistborn Era 5.

appearances.description: Hoid is the narrator and a prominent character.

connections.description: Hoid refers to the Shattering of Adonalsium in Tress of the Emerald Sea chapter 39 and chapter 56. The strange metal seen on Xisis, dragonsteel is what 'Dragonsteel' gets is name from.
Zephyr aether is referenced as a means of propulsion useful for spaceships.

children.title: Yumi and the Nightmare Painter
children.chronology: The story takes place later than everything else in the published Cosmere (as of December 2023) except for Sixth of the Dusk.

appearances.description: Hoid is the narrator and a prominent character.

connections.description: Nomad appears to Skip to UTol, the planetary neighbor of Komashi.

children.title: The Sunlit Man
children.chronology: The story takes place in the space age of the cosmere, at least a few hundred years after Mistborn Era 3. It is unclear where the story falls relative to the Arcanum Unbounded essays, Sixth of the Dusk, and Mistborn Era 5.

appearances.description: Hoid is 'Wit'.
Nomad refers to a law of nature known as 'Khriss's Second Law.

connections:.description: The titular Night Brigade first appeared chasing Nomad in The Sunlit Man in search of the Dawnshard he once held.

children.title: The Silence Divine
children.chronology: Occurs late in the Stormlight Archive era, around book 8.

connections.description: The Silence Divine is set on Ashyn, the world that the humans fled to Roshar from.

children.title: Untitled Ashyn Book
children.chronology: Unknown

children.title: The Grand Apparatus
children.chronology: Unknown

children.title: Untitled Dan Cosmere novel
children.chronology: Unknown

children.title: Free Fall Burrito World
children.title2: Free Fall Seven Layer Burrito World
children.chronology: Unknown

children.title: Magic Kites YA story
children.chronology: Planned to take place between Mistborn Era 3 and 5.

children.title: White Sand (prose)
children.link: Link to full text found in Brandon's newsletter.
children.chronology: White Sand occurs prior to Elantris.

appearances.description: Khriss is a main character.

connections.description: The White Sand graphic novels are based on the prose version.

children.title: Aether of Night
children.link: Full text available from the 17th Shard.

connections.description: Mraize's collection in Chapter 43 includes pink aether.
Mraize mentions his suit was stained with aether.
Foil is said to be seeking 'control over the aethers'.
TwinSoul can manipulate the aethers.
Lumar's oceans consist of aether spores.

children.title: Imperial Fool
children.chronology: Concerns events shortly before the events of The Emperor's Soul.

appearances.description: Hoid is the 'Imperial Fool'.

children.title: Dragonsteel Prime
children.publication: First published with the Words of Radiance leatherbound Kickstarter in 2024.

children.title: Jasnah deleted scene
children.chronology: Occurs during the early events of Words of Radiance.

children.title: The Traveler
children.chronology: Occurs shortly after Mistborn Era 1.

appearances.description: Hoid is 'the Traveler'.
